column5: Yup, but if it is wintertime, the Bombardier Snowmobile, and later, the power auger.
Only cause I fish hardwater so much...but I would rank portable shelters up there somewhere.
The original list was for the last 75 years.
mister twisters and tube jigs are pretty huge. as is the spinnerbait.

I think that Garry has hit the nail on the head with this one but I agree with Roy ... What about the boat?.  Banjo Minnow  and the Flying Lure..  money down the drain.  Although the Banjo Minnow makes for a nice trailer on a spinnerbait   How about the Popeil Pocket Fisherman?   Randy
HEAR HEAR! Just what I was going to say. Rods after that are merely variations on a theme.
My buddy swears by the banjo minnow he catches tonnes of bass on them I can't catch a cold with the stupid things .
I bet I could catch a laker through the ice on one this winter.
White Spinner Bait...........
The "LIES".    Without them - would the wife let you fish at all ?
You beat me to it !...  I still have mine with the original tackle that came with it...  It used to pull duty as an extra icefishing rod when my kids were small and with my grandkids...
Half the pictures wouldn't be posted here if you didn't have a landing NET. Also, we wouldn't be posting about this if it wasn't for the OFC or the PC
pft, no Mepps spinner?
Without a moments thought I'd put the outboard motor at number 1.

The American Sportfishing Association announced their Top Ten list of influential items that have changed the way people fish.  Think you know what they are?  Without further ado...  1. Original Floating Minnow: 1936 — Rapala Perhaps the most popular and successful lure in history.  2. Spring-loaded Bobber: 1947 — Nibble Nabber Found in almost every angler's tackle box.  3. Mitchell 300: 1949 — Mitchell Who hasn't fished this spinning reel?  4. Creme Worm: 1949 — Creme Lure Company The plastic lure that started it all.  5. Closed Face Spincast Reel: 1949 — Zero Hour Bomb Company How every kid learns to cast.  6. Lowrance Fish Lo-K-Tor: 1957 — Lowrance Known as the "Little Green Box" that introduced anglers to sonar...the first ones were actually red.  7. Monofilament Line: 1958 — DuPont Stren What did they use before mono?  8. Minn Kota Trolling Motor: 1958 — Minn Kota Lets you crowd that other boat... quietly.  9. Fenwick High Modulus Graphite Rod: 1972 — Fenwick Probably started the "hold-the-rod-tip-to-your-throat-and-talk" test.  10. Shakespeare Ugly Stik: 1976 — Shakespeare So tough it could survive a nuclear holocaust.
Sounds about right...I love the description for #8
11.  curly tail grub   12. daredevil  spoon
Great list Garry.  I've still got my first ever reel a Mitchell 300 from the late 70's.  Still works (retired now) and who can forget that loud clicker.
13. Minnkota Ipilot (or wireless remotes in general)
15. Bob Izumi's Real Fishing TV Show (I believe this was the first, if not the longest running fishing show)

I still have a mitchell 300 that my uncle Charlie left me with his fishing tackle, When I bought my first reel, it was the 300. I spent a lot of time at the Grand River using it and I thought it would change fishing forever. I used to have an old level wind Shakespear reel that my aunt made when she worked at the outfit that made them, I remember pulling yards of black line off it and whipping it like a lasso around my head and heaving the line out for my cast. How the spinning reel changed all that is amazing.

As a kid who's first rod was " True Temper " square metal fishing rod I'd put the development of the first fibreglass rods ahead of the listed rod entries.  Edit : grt1 my first reel was also a Shakespeare, made in Hamilton by "Inglis ". green it was .

5. Closed Face Spincast Reel: 1949 — Zero Hour Bomb Company How every kid learns to cast.  Dad must have seen enough bombs during ww2, I learned on a Langley bait caster. I didn`t use one until the mid 90`s, but give me any semi closed face Abu 500 series reels over any zebco.  They make line other than Stren?  Who the heck are their sponsors? Free spool bait casters didn`t get a nod?  Hmmm, star drags? I remember having to thumb the spool for drag.  The right kind of bait casters, left hand retrieve.

The Ugly Stick description makes me laugh.  When they first came out the picture in the ads was a guy bending it over backwards at the tip.  My friend and I were in a Collegiate (think that was the name) Sports in Kitchener, way back then.  I picked one up and attempted to do this, the rod snapped in my hands!!! I looked over at my buddy, said "oh, no! I have to pay for this!!"  We looked around, saw nobody and hightailed it out of the store!  Good times
#10.....Oh don't get me started ......
Not even close to being the first - Red Fisher was doing his thing on TV in the late 1960s, when Bob would have been about 12 years old. In the US, Gaddabout Gaddis was on air even earlier than that.
not to hijack, but, from experience, what size rapala minnow is best for what species of fish?  in what circumstances does it really shine?
No stretch Braided fishing line in mid 80's GPS plotting and electronic maps 90's ish and now side imaging
I would add Braided and Fluorocarbon lines have been important
folks, keep in mind that this list is about two years old so I would hazard a guess it would be a little different today.

The can be cast, trolled. Like any lure they shine when they are the one that is working. I used them as a twitch bait a lot, cast it into a pocket in the lilies or weeds and let it sit. Some times you could see a bass rise behind it and just stare, a little twitch and they were all over it.  I used them from 2 - 7 inches, sort of a match the hatch thing Silver and black or Perch finish always worked the best for me.
Here is what was said 2 years ago:  http://www.ofncommunity.com/forums/index.php?showtopic=25089&st=0&p=262849&hl=American%20sport%20fishing&fromsearch=1entry262849
They forgot the Color-C-Lector!
I don't think you can underestimate the importance of the polarized fishing glasses.
I still have my pop-o-matic bobber from the '60's !! Still catches nothing but the buyer...
I think the boat should be right up there eh?
banjo minnow.
popeils pocket fisherman  Great gift for dad from the kids. I made my dad use his... as an adult i know what that look means now.
